content: When Your Loved One is Angry
Always make sure you are safe. If you need to, don't hesitate to call 911.
When You Are Angry
Stop and take a deep breath.
When You Are Angry
Call a time out. Exit the situation until you can try again when you're less angry.
When You Are Angry
Talk to your loved one in advance about when to call time outs during an argument or disagreement.
When Your Loved One is Angry
Stop and take a deep breath.  Ask your loved one to do the same.
If you Take a Time Out
When you're both feeling less angry, try to come back to the conversation and find a solution that works for both of you.
When Your Loved One is Angry
Try to recognize their triggers or warning signs for getting angry. Make a plan for what to do when you notice one of those triggers or signs.
When You Are Angry
Try to recognize your own triggers or warning signs for getting angry. Make a plan for what to do when you notice one of those triggers or signs.
Know Your "Hot Topics"
What are the things that come up that usually lead to conflict with your loved one? When they come up, handle "hot topics" with care.
Dealing with "Hot Topics"
Approach hot topics carefully! Make sure you're feeling calm enough.  Take time to reflect, and choose your words more carefully.
How to Spend a Time Out
Find something calming to do, like going on a walk, calling a friend, exercising, or reading.
How to Spend a Time Out
Are there activities you and your loved one can do together that don't involve talking?
Taking a Time Out
Make sure you have some go-to activities that relax or soothe you. Do things you enjoy rather than re-hashing the argument in your mind.
Calling for a Time Out
Here's something you can say to your loved one: "I care about this issue and I want to resolve it. But I need some time to think and come back when I'm more clear-headed"
Keep Perspective
Every relationship has conflict.  Tolerating or successfully working through conflicts, even if they're minor, has a way of strengthening relationships.
Avoid Criticizing your Loved One
Criticism can feel like being judged or rejected, and it isn't the best tool for motivating change.
Instead of criticizing your loved one, use "I" statements to state your needs and your feelings.
Feeling Blamed?
Try not to be defensive if you're feeling blamed by your loved one.  See if you can understand what your loved one needs from you before you respond or try to defend yourself.
Show and Ask for Respect

Underneath any conflict, there must be a basic level of trust and respect for one another. Don't tolerate name-calling, ridiculing, disrespect, or disgust.  Take a time out if you're feeling disrespected.
Be Present with your Loved One
Don't just walk away from a conflict, unless one of you needs to take a time out from the situation.
Practice Understanding
Slow down and listen - don't interrupt.
Practice Understanding
Focus on the words and body language your partner is using
Practice Understanding
Show interest, even during a conflict.
Accept Your Loved One
Give your loved one the benefit of the doubt.
Accept Your Loved One
Try not to judge.
Understanding Your Loved One
Use your own words to repeat what you think your loved one is really trying to say.
Understanding Your Loved One
Avoid mind-reading. Don't assume you know what your loved one is thinking.
Understanding Your Loved One
Make sure your loved one knows you can't read minds, and ask them to help you understand their needs by talking.
Understanding Your Loved One
Trying to understand how your loved one feels doesn't mean you agree with them.  Really understanding  their perspective is key to moving forward.
Understanding Your Loved One
Ask lots of questions. Make sure you understand what your loved one is saying.  Correct yourself when you make mistakes.
